metadata.title: Effect of lattice strain on structure, morphology and magneto-dielectric prop- erties of spinel NiGdxFe2-xO4 ferrite nano-crystallites synthesized by sol-gel route

sections.text:
Nanocrystalline powders of Gadolinium (Gd 3+ ) substituted nickel ferrite spinel
(NiGdxFe2-xO4: x = 0.00, 0.025, 0.050, 0.075 and 0.1) samples were synthesized via sol-gel method. Nickel nitrate hexahydrate and Ferric nitrate hexahydrate were used as the precursors and rare earth Gadolinium nitrate hexahydrate [Gd(NO3)3.6H2O] was used as the dopant. The structural, morphological, magnetic and dielectric properties of the synthesized nanoparticles were examined by XRD, FTIR, HRSEM, EDX, TEM, VSM and dielectric studies. The Scherrer method and Williamson-Hall (W-H) method were used to evaluate the crystallite sizes and lattice strain. The crystallite size of NiGdxFe2-xO4 samples were found to decrease from 25 nm to 11 nm with increase in Gd 3+ content. Lattice parameters decrease and lattice strain increases with the increase in Gd 3+ content in the sample. HRSEM images showed the spherical morphology and uniform size distribution. The elemental composition
analysis confirms the stoichiometric presence of expected elements in the samples. The crystallite size and the particle size calculated from the XRD analysis and HRTEM monographs indicate the correlation of the data obtained from both the measurements. Magnetic studies of the samples were performed using vibrating Sample Magnetometer, in which magnetizations (Ms) decrease with increase in Gd 3+ concentration from 36.51emu/gm to 19.69emu/gm. As the gadolinium content was gradually increased, coercivity and remnant magnetization were also decreased. Magnetic anisotropy of nickel ferrite was also found to decrease with increasing gadolinium content. The saturation magnetization values were achieved by using the “Law of Approach (LA) to Saturation magnetization” technique. Specific correlation between magnetic interaction and lattice strain was observed in Gd 3+ substituted nickel ferrite. Dielectric parameters such as dielectric constant and dielectric loss of the prepared samples decrease with increase of applied frequency and increasing of Gd 3+ doping concentration.
Keywords: Gd 3+
substituted NiFe2O4; XRD; Lattice strain; TEM; VSM; Dielectric studies.

sections.heading: 1. INTRODUCTION
sections.text:
Recently, nanostructured semiconductor materials exhibit extraordinary properties
than that of their same bulk-counterparts [1-5] and also demonstrate excellent physicochemical, electro-magnetic, and optical properties, due to their surface and size effects [6-10]. Spinel ferrites with a general formula (MFe2O4: M=Co, Ni, Zn etc) are nowadays becoming highly potential candidates for numerous magnetic applications [11]. Considering the various spinal ferrites, nickel ferrites are a class of magnetic materials that are extensively used in highly advanced technologies like multilayer LC filters [12], multi-layer chip inductor [13] magnetic temperature sensors [14] and also for hybrid circuit devices [15].
Ferrites possessing the spinel structure have remarkable properties such as high
saturation magnetization, large permeability and high electrical resistivity at high frequencies which are very useful forelectronics and magneto-electronics [16-19]. Among all the spinal ferrites, nickel ferrites have gained a lot of attention and are widely investigated due to their large magneto-crystalline anisotropy, moderate saturation magnetization high coercivity, chemical stability and mechanical hardness [20]. The structure, morphology, magnetic and dielectric properties of nickel ferrite play a vital role in designing the magnetic, electronic, microwave and electrochemical devices. The property of NiFe2O4 is dependent on chemistry and microstructure, which in turn depend on the synthesis techniques [21, 22]. Generally, the composition of elements, reactive or processing atmosphere, the ions that substitute Fe 3+ /Fe 2+ ions and the sintering temperature (if any) , are the factors that decide the electrical properties of spinel ferrites at room temperature [23]. Investigations reveal that the substitution of Fe 3+ by rare earth ions tends to distort the structure, which in turn induces a strain and significantly alters the electrical properties [24].
Numerous studies have been carried out on the effect of rare earth substitution on the
properties on nickel ferrite, nickel-zinc ferrite, nickel-copper-zinc ferrite, copper-zinc ferrite, manganese-zinc ferrite etc [25-28]. The results indicate that the influence of rare ions on the spinel ferrites is specific to the type of the rare earth ions that are substituted. Replacing the A or B sites in the spinal lattice with rare earth ions brings about a structural distortion and strains the lattice which in turn increases the electric and magnetic values [29]. The dielectric values of the inverse cubic spinel ferrites play a crucial role in understanding the polarization phenomena, electrical conduction and the trend of the localized charge carriers. Previous studies [30-32] indicated the fact that integration of the rare earth cations into the spinel lattice of nickel ferrite altered the basic electrical and magnetic properties. The saturation magnetization and Curie temperature were lowered due to the substitution of iron with
lanthanides. Also the micro structural parameters like the particle size were also affected. Various researchers [33, 34] have concluded that concentration of rare earth substitution in the spinal ferrites is of primary importance while detailing their electrical properties and magnetic properties. The unique properties and characteristics of these rare earth substituted systems can be attributed to the 4f electronic states.
In the present work, the effect of gadolinium substitution on the crystal structure,
morphological, dielectric and magnetic changes due to the replacement of iron ions by gadolinium ions in the cubic spinel nickel ferrite (NiGdxFe2-xO4: 0.0 ≤ x ≤ 0.1) were studied by employing sol-gel method. The magnetic properties on Gd 3+ substituted nickel ferrite are not only depends on cationic distribution, but also depends on lattice strain in the sample. Hence, the crystal structure and its correlation with room temperature magnetic behavior of NiGdxFe2-xO4 have been explored in the present work. Finally a correlation stuck between lattice strain and magnetization has been reported.

sections.heading: 2.1 Materials
sections.text:
Nickel nitrate hexahydrate [Ni(NO3)2.6H2O], ferric nitrate hexahydrate
[Fe(NO3)3.9H2O], Gadolinium nitrate hexahydrate [Gd(NO3)3.6H2O] were all purchased from MERCK specialities Pvt. Ltd, Mumbai. All the chemicals were used from that without any extra purification.

sections.heading: 2.2 Synthesis of Gadolinium doped nickel ferrites
sections.text:
Nanocrystalline powders of gadolinium substituted nickel ferrite with compositional
formula NiGdxFe2-xO4 (0.0 ≤ x ≤ 0.1) were synthesized by the sol-gel method of synthesis. Nickel nitrate hexahydrate and Ferric nitrate hexahydrate were used as the precursors and
rare earth Gadolinium nitrate hexahydrate [Gd(NO3)3.6H2O] was used as the dopant . The precursors and the dopant were together dissolved in a small amount of ethylene glycol and stirred for 30 minutes on a magnetic stirrer at room temperature until a homogenous mixture was obtained. The mixture was then heated for about 2 hours at 70 ° C until a dry aero gel was formed. The gel so formed was dried in a furnace at 120 ° C for about 3 hours. The obtained dry gel was then ground finely in an agate mortar and further annealed at 600 ° C for 3 hours to get the as prepared sample.

sections.heading: 2.3 Characterization
sections.text:
The phase purity and the structure of the synthesized samples were identified from the
X-Ray diffraction pattern recorded by a Rich Seifert, X-ray diffractometer using monochromatic nickel filtered CuKα (λ=1.5416Å) radiation. SHIMADZU FTIR instrument was employed for recording the FT-IR spectrum in order to study the structural coordination of the samples. Freshly prepared nano powder was mixed with KBr and was then pelletized by a hydraulic press and then the spectrum was recorded in the wavelength ranging from 400 to 4000 cm -1 . High resolution scanning electron microscopy (HRSEM) analysis was performed using a JEOL JSM 6310 operated at 10 kV with energy dispersive X-ray analyzer (EDAX). The morphology and size of the nanoparticles were determined from the TEM and HR-TEM images recorded on a JOEL JEM 3010 with an accelerating voltage of 80 kV and 200 kV respectively. Magnetic measurements were carried out with the Lakeshore (Model 73009) Vibrating Sample Magnetometer (VSM). Dielectric studies of the samples were experimented using a HIOKI 3532-50 LCR HiTESTER.

sections.heading: 3.1 Powder X-Ray Diffraction (XRD) Analysis
sections.text:
Powder XRD analysis carried out over Bragg angles ranging from 20 ° to 80 ° and the
resulting diffractograms of as synthesized NiGdxFe2-xO4 (0.0 ≤ x ≤ 0.1) recorded at room temperature are as shown in Fig. 1. The poor crystallinity with nano-scaled ultrafine nature was indicated by the broad diffraction peaks. All the peaks were found to perfectly match with the crystalline phase of the inverse cubic spinel structure of NiFe2O4 (JCPDS Card No. 074-2081) [35]. It is also evident from Fig. 1 that the width of the prominent peak becomes broader as the proportion of gadolinium is proportionally increased, thereby indicating a decrease in the crystallite size. The Scherer’s equation is used to calculate the average grain size of the particles using the full width half maximum (FWHM) values of the (311) reflection. As seen from the Table 1, it is evident that the addition of gadolinium does bring about a drastic decrease in the particle size. It is a well-known fact that grain growth is influenced by the grain boundary mobility [35].
The average crystallite size varied between 25-11nm with the increase of Gd 3+
concentration from 0.00 to 0.1mmol. The inverse cubic spinal structure is retained without any structural distortion, for all the dopant ratios. The absence of additional peaks is indicative of the fact that gadolinium completely goes as a substituent into the spinel lattice. As the concentration of gadolinium increases a minimal increase in the lattice constant can be expected due to the expected because of the large ionic radius of Gd 3+ (0.0938nm) compared to that of Fe 3+ (0.067nm) [35-37]. Gadolinium ions have the tendency of replacing the Fe 3+ ions and occupying the octahedral (B) sites, which in turn induces an internal stress to distort the lattice and hence expand the unit cell. Jing et al. [38] synthesized samples of gadolinium doped lithium nickel ferrite and have indicated a decrease in the lattice parameter with an increase in gadolinium content. This is due to the compression of the spinel lattice
which is induced by the secondary phase (GdFeO3). In the present study, this possibility is not considered as all the as prepared samples are single-phased. It is to be noted that lattice constant does not entirely depend upon the ionic radii [39].
There could be influences from other factors such as the bond length, long range
attractive Coulomb force, etc, the calculation of which will require an in-depth knowledge regarding the surface structure and shape of the particles in addition to the presence of any surface energy [40, 41]. The Gd 3+ ions generally have a tendency of replacing the Fe 3+ ions in the octahedral sites which can be inferred from the invariance of the lattice constant values for the various dopant ratios.
The crystallite size and strain effect in diffraction pattern can also be determined by
the Williamson-Hall equation for peak broadening (β), strain was assumed to be uniform in all crystallographic direction, βhkl is given by
(1)
Rearranging Eqn. (1) gives
(2)
where β is the full width at half maximum of the XRD peaks, θ is the Bragg angle, K = 0.9 is the shape factor, λ is the x-ray wavelength, D is the size of the crystallite, and ε is the average micro strain. The Williamson- Hall plots (β cosθ versus 4 sinθ) shown in Fig. 2, reveals that for all prominent peaks and applied best linear fitting. From linear plot the data are analyzed by the linear function. Crystallite size was calculated from the Y- intercept and, Lattice strain was obtained from the slope of the linear function analysis [42]. Crystallite size and lattice strain are enlisted in the table 1 for all the samples. It is revealed that the lattice strain of the NiGdxFe2-xO4 samples increases with the increase in Gd concentration. The ionic radii of the Gd 3+ (0.938 Å) ions being larger as compared to Fe 3+ (0.6459 Å) ions occupying octahedral sites which leads to increase the lattice strain [43].
Fig. 2. W-H plots of βhkl versus 4sinθ to estimate the crystallite size and lattice strain for NiGdxFe2-xO4 (0.0 ≤ x ≤ 0.1) samples.

sections.heading: 3.2 FT-IR Analysis
sections.text:
The FTIR spectra of the gadolinium doped nickel ferrite system with a chemical
formula NiGdxFe2-xO4 (0.0 ≤ x ≤ 0.1) are as indicated in Fig. 2(a-e). The FTIR analysis is used as a confirmatory tool to confirm the spinal structure formation in the as prepared nano ferrites samples. The Infra-Red spectra of ferrites generally exhibit two major (υ1) which is usually observed 600-550cm -1 wave number range is caused by the stretching vibrations of the metal- oxygen bonds present in the tetrahedral sub-lattice (A) sites. The lower band (υ2) located in the wave number range of 450-385cm -1 , can be attributed to the intrinsic metaloxygen vibrations located in the octahedral sub lattice (B) sites [44, 45]. Both these absorption bands are the characteristic bands that are expected for the spinel structure of the nano-ferrites sample synthesized using the sol-gel auto combustion technique. The position of these absorption bands mainly depend upon the nature of the cations present and also on the length of the bonds. The band positions recorded for the as prepared samples are listed in Table 2 and are found to be in good agreement with the range already reported for nickel ferrite [46, 47]. The highest band (υ1) observed in the range of 591 – 601cm −1 is attributed to stretching frequency of metal-oxygen bond whereas the lowest band observed in the range 406 – 416 cm −1 (υ2) indicates the vibration mode of octahedral metal oxygen bonds. The spectra also shows the bands near 3440 cm −1 and 1504 cm −1 which are ascribed to H–O stretching and bending vibration modes of free or absorbed water. The band around 2300cm -1 indicates the presence of a residual amount of CO2. The anti-symmetric NO-stretching vibrations produced by the residual nitrates present in the sample give rise to a band around 1400 cm -1 .
As it can be seen from the Table 2, the absorption band γ2 is slightly shifted to a
higher frequency side with addition of gadolinium ions and can be attributed to the increase in bond length on the B-site [48]. This suggests that the rare-earth ions occupy the B-site. It is
evident from the table that the values of γ1 are shifted towards the higher frequency side with increasing gadolinium concentration. This shift in the frequency is due to the increase in the site radius owing to the replacement of the Fe 3+ ions that are smaller than the Gd 3+ ions present in the octahedral sites. Similar results have been reported for Tb 3+ doped nickel ferrite nanoparticles by Khan et al. [49]. The intensities of the absorption peaks are found to decrease with increasing gadolinium doping, which is indicative of a disordered state of the ferrite sample caused due to doping [50]. The difference in frequencies between the higher and lower absorption bands is due to changes in bond length (Fe 3+ O 2− ) at tetrahedral and octahedral sites respectively [51].
Fig. 2. FT-IR spectrum of NiGdxFe2-xO4 (0.0 ≤ x ≤ 0.1) ferrite nanoparticles.

sections.heading: 3.3 High Resolution Scanning Electron Microscopy (HR-SEM) and EDX analysis
sections.text:
lattice see Fig. 4(a-e). The high purity of the as prepared samples was confirmed by the absence of any impurities in the EDX spectra.
Fig. 4. EDX spectra of NiGdxFe2-xO4 ((a) x= 0.00, (b) x= 0.025, (c) x= 0.050, (d) x= 0.075, (e) x= 0.1) spinel nanoparticles.

sections.heading: 3.4 Transmission Electron Microscopy (TEM) Analysis
sections.text:
The TEM images with different magnifications for the NiGdxFe2-xO4 (x = 0.025) nano
sample are as shown in Fig. 5(a-c).The samples were suspended in a liquid (water) and the suspensions were dropped on forever coated grids, dried and then viewed under a transmission electron microscope operated at an accelerating voltage of 80 kV. The images so obtained clearly indicate the formation of the nanoparticles. In all the micrographs it is evident that all the particles appear spherical in shape and slightly agglomerated. Complete agglomeration is visible in a few particles, thereby making them look like large particles. The average size of the particles as recorded in the TEM images was around 35 nm for the pristine sample and around 20 nm for the gadolinium doped nickel ferrite nanosamples thereby indicating the fact that gadolinium substitution has indeed brought about a considerable decrease in the particle size. This fact is evident from the TEM images of pure and gadolinium doped nickel ferrites represented in the Fig. 5(a) and (b) respectively. The crystallite sizes obtained from the TEM micrographs are found to be in close approximation with the values obtained from the XRD analysis.

sections.heading: 3.5. High-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HR-TEM) study
sections.text:
An in-depth high resolution transmission electron microscopy study was done to
analyze the nano–scaled fine structure of the Gd 3+
doped nickel ferrite system, NiGdxFe2-xO4
(x=0.025). The high resolution TEM (HR TEM) image of a single nano particle was taken
and is as shown in the Fig. 6. It is evident from the figure that the nano particle is single crystalline in nature, with clear lattice fringes that can be observed on the entire particle. Majority of particles are found to be dominantly faceted into crystallites. Atomic planes for the lattice system are clearly visible with a d spacing of of about .0.245-0.229 nm.

sections.heading: 3.6 Selected Area Electron Diffraction (SAED) analyses
sections.text:
Crystallographic interpretations of the as prepared sample were done in the reciprocal
space by recording the Selected Area Electron Diffraction patterns (SAED) of NiGdxFe2-xO4 (x=0.025) nano sample. Fig. 7 shows a SAED pattern of gadolinium doped nickel ferrite from an aggregate of nanoparticles. A set of important Debye rings corresponding to hkl planes: 311 (d = 0.3194 nm), 400 (d = 0.2708 nm), 511 (d = 0.1826 nm) and 440 (d = 0.1699 nm) of the basic nickel ferrite cubic crystal structure (space group: Fd3m, a = 8.3379 Å) are marked in Fig. 7. These Debye rings appeared to be continuous and are diffused, which further corroborates that the sample is very much in the nano regime. The observed crystallographic "d" values agree well with those obtained from XRD analysis.
Fig. 6 Different magnifications for the HR-TEM images of gadolinium doped nickel ferrite.
Fig. 7 SAED image for gadolinium doped nickel ferrite

sections.heading: 3.7 VSM Analysis
sections.text:
To analyze the effects of gadolinium substitution on saturation magnetization,
coercivity and remnant magnetization, M-H hysteresis loops were recorded using vibrating sample magnetometer operated at an applied magnetic field of 10 k Oe at room temperature. Figure 8represents the hysteresis curves of all samples of spinel NiGdxFe2-xO4 (0.0 ≤ x ≤ 0.1). The values of the magnetic parameters such as saturation magnetization (MS), coercivity (HC) and remanence (Mr) are given in Table 3. A well-defined S shaped curve is exhibited by all the samples. The saturation magnetization and coercivity exhibit a decreasing trend with increasing gadolinium concentration. This decrease can be justified as being due to the replacement of Fe 3+ present at the B-sites by the Gd 3+ ions.The magnetic moment of Gd 3+ ions are higher (7 μB) compared to the Fe 3+ ions (5 μB). The ordering of the magnetic moments of rare earth ions is much below room temperature [52, 53] due to which, at room temperature the Gd ion is non-magnetic thereby causing a decrease in saturation magnetization and coercivity. The octahedral (B) sites are occupied by Gd 3+ ions in place of Fe 3+ , due to their comparatively larger ionic radius. Rare earth metal ions are nonmagnetic and do not contribute to the magnetization of doped ferrites at room temperature [54]. The magnetization in the B sub-lattice decreases, thereby decreasing the A-B interaction due to the existence of Gd 3+
ions on the B sites resulting in the decrease of MS [55, 56]. The
decrease in particle size caused by the substitution of Gd 3+ ions can be another reason for the decrease in MS with increasing gadolinium concentration. Previous researches established the fact that the porosity was found to be inversely related, while the particle size was directly proportional to the saturation magnetization in nanoferrites [57]. The remanent magnetizations are found to be almost decreasing with the increase in Gd concentration. It could be due to strain at the lattice site. Coercivity of ferrites is reported to be influenced by factors like particle morphology, micro strain, anisotropy, porosity, size distribution and the
size of the magnetic domain [54]. This substitution is expected to cause a lattice distortion and hence alter the magnetic characteristics of materials. However in the present study, gadolinium was successfully incorporated into the spinel lattice of nickel ferrite without any structural distortion. Factors like cation substitution, grain size and A-B exchange interactions are found to largely influence the magnetic properties of ferrite materials. Increase in the grain size and decrease of A-B super exchange interaction causes canting spins at the surface of nanoparticles that decreases the magnetic characteristics of the present samples as shown in Fig. 8. The listed magnetic parameters indicate the fact that the soft magnetic nature nickel ferrite was lost by the substitution of gadolinium. Moderately high coercivity together with modest saturation magnetization makes these ferrites desirable for being used in memory devices and magnetic recording. Considering the values listed in Table 3, it is evident that gadolinium doping can render the nickel ferrite nanoparticles to be highly desirable for such applications.
Fig. 8 Magnetic hysteresis curves of NiGdxFe2-xO4 (0.0 ≤ x ≤ 0.1) spinel nanoparticles.
The saturation magnetization (Ms) has been obtained from the magnetic hysteresis
loop by employing the “Law of approach (LA) to saturation” method. It is generally used for extracting the two important parameters such as saturation magnetization (Ms) and magnetocrystalline anisotropy field (B) for ferromagnetic materials. The LA to saturation is defined as [58, 59]
(3)
Hence, Ms is the saturation magnetization; A is the constant depends on material
property (itcomes from inhomogeneities of samples) and B is constant associated to the magnetocrystalline anisotropy of the samples and xH is the high-field differential susceptibility related to the spontaneous magnetization of the domains, it is active in the high temperature analysis. Hence, the second part of equation 3 (i.e. 4th term) is not considered for analysis. Also the A/H term does not give any significant value. The constant A has been approximate to zero. Hence, the above equation (2) reduced to,
(4)
The experimental data of Magnetization (M) versus applied magnetic field (1/H 2 ) plot
becomes linear in the magnetic field between 7.5 kOe and 12.5 kOe. These linear lines are analyzed by the modified Law of approach to saturation for all the samples, which are depicted in the Fig. 9. The circles represent the experimental data and the linear solid line represents the theoretical data to the LA to saturation. The intercepts of the straight line give the saturation magnetizations (Ms) and slope gives the B value. The anisotropy field can be determined by the relation [59]
(5)
The saturation magnetizations (Ms) for all the samples are obtained from the intercept of the linear curve. Magnetocrysalline anisotropy field is calculated from the slope of the
linearcurve with the help of equation 5. All the determined parameters (Ms, Mr, B) are enlisted in Table 3.
Fig. 9. Magnetization versus 1/H 2 plots of NiGdxFe2-xO4 ((0.0 ≤ x ≤ 0.1)). It is examined by using the “Law of Approach to saturation” (straight line) model.
Fig. 9. The saturation magnetization (Ms) and lattice strain versus Gd concentration in NiGdxFe2-xO4 (0.0 ≤ x ≤ 0.1) spinel nanoparticles.

sections.heading: 3.8 Dielectric Measurements
sections.text:
Variation of dielectric constant with frequency
The dielectric constant can be defined as the measure of the degree up to which a
medium gets polarized in the presence of applied electric fields. Nanocrystalline spinal ferrites in general are good dielectric materials, depending upon the cation distribution, particle size, and the mode of synthesis. The dielectric parameters of Gd 3+ doped ferrites have been investigated by Ahmed [60] and Muthafar [61]. Fig. 9(a-e) shows the variation of dielectric constant as a function of frequency for various temperatures for all the samples. in the frequency range 100Hz to 20MHz. Normal dielectric behavior was exhibited by all the compositions [62]. The dielectric constant graphs indicate a decreasing trend with increasing frequencies, eventually attaining constant values at higher frequencies, which is a trend specific to all ferrites [63, 64]. The mechanism of dielectric polarization and electric conduction are similar in the case of ferrites [65, 66]. The hopping of electrons and holes between Fe 2+ and Fe 3+ ions and between Ni 3+ and Ni 2+ ions on the octahedral sites
respectively, facilitate the electrical conduction, thereby locally displacing the electrons in the direction of applied electric field and resulting in the dielectric polarization. This type of dielectric dispersion observed in the case of ferrites can be understood using the MaxwellWagner model and Koop’s theory [65,66], according to which the ferrite system in general is considered to be made up of a heterogeneous mixture of highly conducting grains that are separated by grain boundaries that are not very good conductors. The variation of dielectric constant with frequency is as shown the Figure 10 (a-e). The decrease in the dielectric constant can be justified to be due to the replacement of the Fe 3+ ions by the Gd 3+ ions with a stable valency, which decreases the rate of hopping. The electron exchange between Fe 2+ ↔Fe 3+ results are in the dielectric polarization. The magnitude of this polarization depends on the percentage of Fe 2+ / Fe 3+ ion pairs that are located at the A and B sites. The concentration of the Fe 2+ ions influences the conduction and mainly depends on the synthesis route, cation substitution, sintering time and temperatures. The decreasing trend of dielectric constant with increasing frequency as observed in the gadolinium doped nickel ferrite samples is a normal dielectric behavior specific to ferrites. The same dielectric behavior was observed by many other investigators too [67-69]. This characteristic dielectric behavior of these spinel ferrites was explained in depth by Rezlescu and Rezlescu [70].
Fig. 10. Variation of dielectric constant with frequency for NiGd xFe2-xO4 ((a) x= 0.00, (b) x= 0.025, (c) x= 0.050, (d) x= 0.075, (e) x= 0.1) spinel nanoparticles.
(a )
(b )
(c )
(d )
(e )
Variation of dielectric loss with frequency
The variation of dielectric loss (ε”) with frequency is as shown the Figure 11 (a-e).
This behaviour is a characteristic behaviour of the ferrite system specifically the gadolinium doped nickel ferrite system. The plots of the dielectric loss as indicated in the graphs for varying gadolinium concentration indicated a rapid decrease in the dielectric loss in the lower frequency region. The rate of decrease however slowed down and almost became a constant in the higher frequency region. This behavior can be justified using the Koop’s phenomenological theory. Affording to this theory, the low frequency region contains very poorly conducting grain boundaries that are active due to which the hopping of electrons requires more energy. In the high frequency region, the highly conducting grains become activated because of which the energy required for hopping decreases [71-73]. The variation of dielectric loss (ε”) recorded at different increasing temperatures, as a function of frequency with respect to the sample under study is as shown in Figure 11(a-e). All the nano ferrite samples exhibited the normal dielectric behavior. Comparable results are reported for yttrium doped nickel ferrite and gadolinium doped magnesium ferrite.
Fig. 11. Variation of dielectric loss with frequency for NiGdxFe2-xO4 ((a) x= 0.00, (b) x= 0.025, (c) x= 0.050, (d) x= 0.075, (e) x= 0.1) spinel nanoparticles.
(a) (b)
(c)
(e)
(d)

sections.heading: 4. Conclusion
sections.text:
Ultra-fine nanoparticles of gadolinium doped nickel ferrite have been successfully
synthesized using the sol-gel technique. Gadolinium substitution has brought about remarkable improvement in the structural, dielectric and magnetic properties of nickel ferrite. The XRD analysis confirmed the formation of nanocrystalline cubic spinel structure. The Crystallite size of synthesized nanoparticles was calculated by Debye-Scherer formula which decreases from 25 nm to 11 nm. Lattice parameters, particle size decreases and lattice strain increases with the increase in Gd 3+ content in the sample. The values of the crystallite size and the particle size calculated from the XRD analysis and HR-TEM monographs indicate the correlation of the data obtained from both the measurements. FTIR absorption bands observed around 412 cm −1 and 592 cm −1 corresponds to tetrahedral and octahedral sites which confirmed the formation of single phase cubic structure of ferrites. Gadolinium substitution has influenced the magnetic properties of nickel ferrite nanoparticles to a large extent. Saturation magnetization, coercivity and remnant magnetization were found to be decreased with increasing gadolinium content, thereby the magnetic anisotropy of nickel ferrite was found to decrease with increasing gadolinium content. Coercivity with small values revealed that the prepared nanomaterials NiGdxFe2-xO4 have soft magnetic nature. Modest values of coercivity together with magnetization make these as prepared samples of nickel gadolinium ferrites most suitable for memory and magnetic recording devices. A correlation between lattice strain and magnetization of NiGdxFe2-xO4 has been discussed. The dielectric constant and dielectric loss were found to decrease with substitution of Gd 3+ composition. The prepared nanoparticles have low dielectric loss and could be a potential material for high frequency applications.

sections.text: The authors are grateful to Dept. of Nuclear Physics, University of Madras, Chennai, for Powder XRD analysis.

Investigations reveal that the substitution of Fe 3+ by rare earth ions tends to distort the structure, which in turn induces a strain and significantly alters the electrical properties [24].

metadata.abstractText: Nanocrystalline powders of Gadolinium (Gd 3+ ) substituted nickel ferrite spinel (NiGdxFe2-xO4: x = 0.00, 0.025, 0.050, 0.075 and 0.1) samples were synthesized via sol-gel method. Nickel nitrate hexahydrate and Ferric nitrate hexahydrate were used as the precursors and rare earth Gadolinium nitrate hexahydrate [Gd(NO3)3.6H2O] was used as the dopant. The structural, morphological, magnetic and dielectric properties of the synthesized nanoparticles were examined by XRD, FTIR, HRSEM, EDX, TEM, VSM and dielectric studies. The Scherrer method and Williamson-Hall (W-H) method were used to evaluate the crystallite sizes and lattice strain. The crystallite size of NiGdxFe2-xO4 samples were found to decrease from 25 nm to 11 nm with increase in Gd 3+ content. Lattice parameters decrease and lattice strain increases with the increase in Gd 3+ content in the sample. HRSEM images showed the spherical morphology and uniform size distribution. The elemental composition
